elements.content: Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials play an important role in coordination chemistry. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a Co­(II)-based MOF [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (1). Single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure. The magnetic properties studies indicate that compound 1 shows easy-plane anisotropy with positive D value, which is further proved by high-field electron paramagnetic resonance (HF-EPR). AC susceptibility measurements show that compound 1 is field-induced SMM governed by single Co­(II) ion. The magnetic properties studies indicate that coordinate halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. However, the secondary coordination environment of packing pattern has a significant effect on the slow relaxation.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials play an important role in coordination chemistry. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a Co(II)-based MOF [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (1). Single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure. The magnetic properties studies indicate that compound 1 shows easy-plane anisotropy with positive D value, which is further proved by high-field electron paramagnetic resonance (HF-EPR). AC susceptibility measurements show that compound 1 is field-induced SMM governed by single Co(II) ion. The magnetic properties studies indicate that coordinate halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. However, the secondary coordination environment of packing pattern has a significant effect on the slow relaxation.

elements.content:
This manuscript reports single-ion magnets behavior of cobalt-based MOFs. The effects of packing mode and coordinated halogen atoms on the slow relaxation process were investigated.

Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Molecular Magnets and Switchable Magnetic Materials

Introduction

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received a myriad of attention due to their potential applications in adsorption, catalysis, luminescence, electrical conductivity, and magnetic properties. Among them, the magnetic properties, especially single-molecule magnets (SMMs), have been favored by researchers because of their potential application in spintronics and quantum computers, etc. Plenty of MOFs showing slow relaxation behavior governed by single Ln­(III) ion have been reported, since the Ln­(III) ions have strong magnetic anisotropy from spin orbit coupling. Like Ln­(III) ions, the transition-metal ions, especially Co­(II) ions, can also exhibit strong magnetic anisotropy. However, there are few MOFs showing slow relaxation of magnetization behavior governed by transition-metal ions have been published so far.
elements.clean_text:
This manuscript reports single-ion magnets behavior of cobalt-based MOFs. The effects of packing mode and coordinated halogen atoms on the slow relaxation process were investigated.

Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Molecular Magnets and Switchable Magnetic Materials

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received a myriad of attention due to their potential applications in adsorption, catalysis, luminescence, electrical conductivity, and magnetic properties. Among them, the magnetic properties, especially single-molecule magnets (SMMs), have been favored by researchers because of their potential application in spintronics and quantum computers, etc. Plenty of MOFs showing slow relaxation behavior governed by single Ln(III) ion have been reported, since the Ln(III) ions have strong magnetic anisotropy from spin orbit coupling. Like Ln(III) ions, the transition-metal ions, especially Co(II) ions, can also exhibit strong magnetic anisotropy. However, there are few MOFs showing slow relaxation of magnetization behavior governed by transition-metal ions have been published so far.

elements.content: The effective energy barrier of the transition-metal-ion-based SMMs is expressed as U = |D|S 2 or U = |D|(S 2 – 1/4). Thus, compounds can show slow relaxation behavior when they have sufficiently large anisotropy (D). For MOF materials, in addition to magnetic anisotropy of metal centers, we need to consider magnetic coupling between nearest metal ions and the rigidity of ligands effects on its slow relaxation. However, it is still a promising way to use mononuclear complexes showing SMM behavior as precursors for assembling MOFs, which can retain the slow relaxation behavior of single ions.
elements.clean_text: The effective energy barrier of the transition-metal-ion-based SMMs is expressed as U = |D|S 2 or U = |D|(S 2 - 1/4). Thus, compounds can show slow relaxation behavior when they have sufficiently large anisotropy (D). For MOF materials, in addition to magnetic anisotropy of metal centers, we need to consider magnetic coupling between nearest metal ions and the rigidity of ligands effects on its slow relaxation. However, it is still a promising way to use mononuclear complexes showing SMM behavior as precursors for assembling MOFs, which can retain the slow relaxation behavior of single ions.

elements.content: Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a 2D Co­(II) MOF, [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (1) governed by single Co­(II) ions. We choose Co­(II) ions for the metal center and dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps) as the link to construct the layered MOF structure. The compound is composed of 2D layered materials and feature a 2-fold interpenetrating framework. Correspond measurements of 1 allow us to obtain insight into the magnetic properties, which allows us to make a comparison with previously reported two related compounds, [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (2) and [Co­(dps)2Br2] n (3). The results indicate that the different coordination halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. The packing differences lead to a longer relaxation but smaller energy barrier. This study further confirmed that the secondary coordination environment has a significant effect on the slow relaxation of SMMs.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a 2D Co(II) MOF, [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (1) governed by single Co(II) ions. We choose Co(II) ions for the metal center and dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps) as the link to construct the layered MOF structure. The compound is composed of 2D layered materials and feature a 2-fold interpenetrating framework. Correspond measurements of 1 allow us to obtain insight into the magnetic properties, which allows us to make a comparison with previously reported two related compounds, [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (2) and [Co(dps)2Br2] n  (3). The results indicate that the different coordination halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. The packing differences lead to a longer relaxation but smaller energy barrier. This study further confirmed that the secondary coordination environment has a significant effect on the slow relaxation of SMMs.

elements.content: The compound 1 was synthesized through the reaction of dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps) and CoCl2·6H2O in water and compound 2 in the literature was obtained via the reaction of dps and CoCl2·6H2O in methanol. Therefore, compounds 1 and 2 have different packing patterns. The Co­(II) atom are proved to have a valency of 2+, as revealed by their charge balance considerations and Co–N/O bond lengths.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The compound 1 was synthesized through the reaction of dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps) and CoCl2⋅6H2O in water and compound 2 in the literature was obtained via the reaction of dps and CoCl2⋅6H2O in methanol. Therefore, compounds 1 and 2 have different packing patterns. The Co(II) atom are proved to have a valency of 2+, as revealed by their charge balance considerations and Co-N/O bond lengths.

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction results indicate that 1 is crystallized in the Pccn space group (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The coordination geometry of the metal center Co­(II) is distorted six-coordinate octahedral configuration in 1 (). All of the Co–N bonds length are in normal range in 1. The bonds length of the Co–Cl is 2.419 Å. The nearest Co­(II) ions are connected by dps ligands, which constitute a 2D structure in the ac plane with a frame size of 11.1390 Å for 1 (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). These two 2D frame are 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework in the same layer (). The nearest layer was connected by hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Single-crystal diffraction results indicate that 1 is crystallized in the Pccn space group (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The coordination geometry of the metal center Co(II) is distorted six-coordinate octahedral configuration in 1 (). All of the Co-N bonds length are in normal range in 1. The bonds length of the Co-Cl is 2.419 Å. The nearest Co(II) ions are connected by dps ligands, which constitute a 2D structure in the ac plane with a frame size of 11.1390 Å for 1 (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). These two 2D frame are 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework in the same layer (). The nearest layer was connected by hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: (Left) Structural diagrams of the asymmetric units of compound 1. (Right) 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework for 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (Left) Structural diagrams of the asymmetric units of compound 1. (Right) 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework for 1.

elements.content: The Co­(II) ions in compound 1 and previously reported related compounds 2 and 3 are octahedron coordination geometries, which are proved by calculation results from SHAPE 2.1 software (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information and ). Compounds 1 and 2 are almost the same, but differ in the packing. The configuration of compound 3 deviates the most from the octahedron, because of the large radius of the Br– ion. The C–S–C bond angles of the dps ligand are 104.34°, 104.91°, and 104.21° for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, compound 2 is (4,4)-connected framework in the same layer, while compounds 1 and 3 are the occurrence of a 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework interwoven sheets. The nearest Co···Co distance in compound 2 is larger than that in compounds 1 and 3, which is due to the larger C–S–C angle of dps (see Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Thus, there are no interactions and intraactions between Co­(II) ions in 2. Compounds 1 and 2 have the same coordination geometry of Co­(II) ions but different packing. In adition, compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing but different coordinate halogen ions (see ).
elements.clean_text: The Co(II) ions in compound 1 and previously reported related compounds 2 and 3 are octahedron coordination geometries, which are proved by calculation results from SHAPE 2.1 software (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information and ). Compounds 1 and 2 are almost the same, but differ in the packing. The configuration of compound 3 deviates the most from the octahedron, because of the large radius of the Br- ion. The C-S-C bond angles of the dps ligand are 104.34°, 104.91°, and 104.21° for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, compound 2 is (4,4)-connected framework in the same layer, while compounds 1 and 3 are the occurrence of a 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework interwoven sheets. The nearest Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance in compound 2 is larger than that in compounds 1 and 3, which is due to the larger C-S-C angle of dps (see Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Thus, there are no interactions and intraactions between Co(II) ions in 2. Compounds 1 and 2 have the same coordination geometry of Co(II) ions but different packing. In adition, compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing but different coordinate halogen ions (see ).

elements.content: Schematic representation of the topology of compounds (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3.
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic representation of the topology of compounds (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3.

elements.content: Direct-current (DC) susceptibilities of polycrystalline sample were measured under a 1.0 kOe field with a temperature range of 2–300 K. As shown in , the χM T value at 300 K is 3.20 cm3 mol–1 K for 1, which is larger than the theoretical spin-only value of 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K for an isolated high-spin Co­(II) ion (S = 3/2 and g = 2.0). This is due to the contribution of the spin–orbit coupling of Co­(II) ion: upon cooling, the χM T value decreases slowly from room temperature to 150 K and then fast between 150 K and 2 K, reaching a minima value of 1.92 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K.
elements.clean_text:
DC Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (DC) susceptibilities of polycrystalline sample were measured under a 1.0 kOe field with a temperature range of 2-300 K. As shown in , the χM T value at 300 K is 3.20 cm3 mol-1 K for 1, which is larger than the theoretical spin-only value of 1.875 cm3 mol-1 K for an isolated high-spin Co(II) ion (S = 3/2 and g = 2.0). This is due to the contribution of the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) ion: upon cooling, the χM T value decreases slowly from room temperature to 150 K and then fast between 150 K and 2 K, reaching a minima value of 1.92 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χM T vs T plots for 1. Inset shows experimental and theoretical M vs HT–1 plots at different temperatures for 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of χM T vs T plots for 1. Inset shows experimental and theoretical M vs HT-1 plots at different temperatures for 1.

elements.content: The field-dependent magnetization of compound 1 was measured in the temperature range from 1.8 to 10 K at the magnetic fields between 0 and 7 T (). The field-dependent magnetizations of compound 1 at 1.8 K and 7 T is below the theoretical saturation value. The plots of M vs HT–1 at different temperature do not overlap clearly (), which confirm the existence of significant magnetic anisotropy attributed to the strong spin–orbit coupling of Co­(II). The data of field-dependent magnetization and temperature was fitted by the PHI program to quantify the anisotropy parameters for 1 using the following spin Hamiltonian: Ĥ = D [ Ŝ z 2 − S ( S + 1 ) 3 ] + E ( Ŝ x 2 − Ŝ y 2 ) + g μ B S H where D and E represent the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting (ZFC) and the last part is the Zeeman. The best fitting results parameters are D = 104.57 cm–1, E = 0.13 cm–1, g = 2.64, and TIP = 1.3 × 10–4 cm3 mol–1 for 1. The positive D values indicate that 1 is easy-plan magnetic anisotropy.
elements.clean_text: The field-dependent magnetization of compound 1 was measured in the temperature range from 1.8 to 10 K at the magnetic fields between 0 and 7 T (). The field-dependent magnetizations of compound 1 at 1.8 K and 7 T is below the theoretical saturation value. The plots of M vs HT-1 at different temperature do not overlap clearly (), which confirm the existence of significant magnetic anisotropy attributed to the strong spin-orbit coupling of Co(II). The data of field-dependent magnetization and temperature was fitted by the PHI program to quantify the anisotropy parameters for 1 using the following spin Hamiltonian:    Ĥ = D  [    Ŝ   z    2   -   S  ( S + 1 )    3   ]  + E  (    Ŝ   x    2   -    Ŝ   y    2   )  + g   μ   B   S H   where D and E represent the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting (ZFC) and the last part is the Zeeman. The best fitting results parameters are D = 104.57 cm-1, E = 0.13 cm-1, g = 2.64, and TIP = 1.3 × 10-4 cm3 mol-1 for 1. The positive D values indicate that 1 is easy-plan magnetic anisotropy.

elements.content: To study the dynamic magnetic properties for compound 1, ac susceptibilities, as a function of frequency, were measured at a certain temperature under different applied dc fields from 0 to 3.0 kOe (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). No out-of-phase (χM ′′) ac signals were observed for 1 under zero dc field, while clear signals were observed under low dc field. This phenomenon indicates that compound 1 has quantum tunnelling of magnetization (QTM) and shows field-induced slow relaxation behavior. Thus, 1500 Oe was chosen to measure χM ′′ vs υ curves at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text:
AC Magnetic Properties

To study the dynamic magnetic properties for compound 1, ac susceptibilities, as a function of frequency, were measured at a certain temperature under different applied dc fields from 0 to 3.0 kOe (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). No out-of-phase (χM '') ac signals were observed for 1 under zero dc field, while clear signals were observed under low dc field. This phenomenon indicates that compound 1 has quantum tunnelling of magnetization (QTM) and shows field-induced slow relaxation behavior. Thus, 1500 Oe was chosen to measure χM '' vs υ curves at different temperatures.

elements.content: ac susceptibilities were measured at different temperatures from 1.8 K to 7.0 K under a 1500 Oe dc field (). The Cole–Cole plots of χM ′′ vs χM ′ show semicircles for compound 1 from 1.8 K to 6.0 K and can be fitted well using a generalized Debye model by using CC-FIT software (). Therefore, the while frequency-dependent data extracted from Cole–Cole plots in the temperature range of 1.8–5.8 K was fitted by , including three possible relaxation processes: the direct process, the Raman process, and the Orbach process. For , B is the direct coefficient, C and n are coefficients of the Raman process, U eff is the effective energy barrier, T is the temperature, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. The best fitting gave parameters of B = 123.67K –1 S –1, C = 0.707K –n S –1, n = 5.04, τo = 8.82 × 10–7 s and U eff = 28.56 cm–1. τ − 1 = B T + C T n + τ 0 − 1 exp ( − U eff k B T ) From the previous structural analysis, we understand that compounds 1 and 2 have the same formula but different packing patterns and compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing arrangement but different halogen ligands. By comparing the relaxation processes of compounds 1–3, it was found that the relaxation time of compound 2 was the longest, as shown in . In addition, the effective energy barrier of compound 2 was lowest. Since compound 2 does not have the 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework, the distance between Co­(II) in the same plane is the largest, compared to 1 and 3, which probably leads to the lowest energy barrier and the longest relaxation time of 2.
elements.clean_text: ac susceptibilities were measured at different temperatures from 1.8 K to 7.0 K under a 1500 Oe dc field (). The Cole-Cole plots of χM '' vs χM ' show semicircles for compound 1 from 1.8 K to 6.0 K and can be fitted well using a generalized Debye model by using CC-FIT software (). Therefore, the while frequency-dependent data extracted from Cole-Cole plots in the temperature range of 1.8-5.8 K was fitted by , including three possible relaxation processes: the direct process, the Raman process, and the Orbach process. For , B is the direct coefficient, C and n are coefficients of the Raman process, U eff is the effective energy barrier, T is the temperature, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. The best fitting gave parameters of B = 123.67K -1 S -1, C = 0.707K -n  S -1, n = 5.04, τo = 8.82 × 10-7 s and U eff = 28.56 cm-1.      τ   - 1   = B T +   C T   n   +     τ   0     - 1    exp  (   -   U   eff       k   B   T   )    1 From the previous structural analysis, we understand that compounds 1 and 2 have the same formula but different packing patterns and compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing arrangement but different halogen ligands. By comparing the relaxation processes of compounds 1-3, it was found that the relaxation time of compound 2 was the longest, as shown in . In addition, the effective energy barrier of compound 2 was lowest. Since compound 2 does not have the 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework, the distance between Co(II) in the same plane is the largest, compared to 1 and 3, which probably leads to the lowest energy barrier and the longest relaxation time of 2.

elements.content: Frequency-dependent in-phase (left) and out-of phase (right) AC susceptibilities signals in 1.5 kOe for 1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Frequency-dependent in-phase (left) and out-of phase (right) AC susceptibilities signals in 1.5 kOe for 1.

elements.content: Cole–Cole curves for 1 (a). Solid lines are the best fit obtained with Debye model.
elements.clean_text: 5  Cole-Cole curves for 1 (a). Solid lines are the best fit obtained with Debye model.

elements.content: Although compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing patterns, the difference in ligand halogens leads to the different behavior of the slow relaxation. The greater electronegativity of the Cl– ion than the Br– ion results in different electron cloud densities for the Co­(II) ions of 1 and 3. The effective energy barriers of compound 3 are higher than those of compound 1. Our work further confirms that the secondary coordination environment has a significant effect on the slow magnetic relaxation of 2D MOF structure governed by single ions.
elements.clean_text: Although compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing patterns, the difference in ligand halogens leads to the different behavior of the slow relaxation. The greater electronegativity of the Cl- ion than the Br- ion results in different electron cloud densities for the Co(II) ions of 1 and 3. The effective energy barriers of compound 3 are higher than those of compound 1. Our work further confirms that the secondary coordination environment has a significant effect on the slow magnetic relaxation of 2D MOF structure governed by single ions.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 3 have different topology compared to the other 2-D cobalt-based SMMs with MOF structure in (presented later in this work). Compounds 1 and 3 have 2-fold interspersed stacking patterns, whereas the other compounds do not have a similar topology. As shown in (presented later in this work), it is clear that the axial halogen ions are better than water molecules in such systems and the secondary solvent molecules also have a significant effect on the magnetic properties. Furthermore, the negative axial ions are more favorable than neutral ligands. However, it is impossible to draw any conclusions since there are too few samples.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 3 have different topology compared to the other 2-D cobalt-based SMMs with MOF structure in  (presented later in this work). Compounds 1 and 3 have 2-fold interspersed stacking patterns, whereas the other compounds do not have a similar topology. As shown in  (presented later in this work), it is clear that the axial halogen ions are better than water molecules in such systems and the secondary solvent molecules also have a significant effect on the magnetic properties. Furthermore, the negative axial ions are more favorable than neutral ligands. However, it is impossible to draw any conclusions since there are too few samples.

elements.content: In order to further confirm the magnetic anisotropy of compound 1, HF-EPR measurements were performed in the frequency range of 54–315 GHz at 4.2 K. Three main signals can be observed in the HF-EPR spectra of compound 1, which are typical for a spin S = 3/2 Co­(II) system with large and positive D values, and they are attributable to the intra-Kramers transitions within the M s = ±1/2 doublets with ΔM s = ±1 (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The field versus frequency dependence of these signals are shown in Figure S5. The simulations of HF-EPR spectra of the compounds utilize the estimated D values (+100 cm–1 for 1) extracted from magnetic measurements. The best parameters obtained are as follows: a g-tensor [g x = g y = 2.66, g z = 3.31], D = +100 cm–1, and |E| = 32.57 for 1. The results further confirmed that the sign of the D value is positive. Meanwhile, the red simulated spectrum (D > 0) is in good agreement with the experimental spectrum while the blue simulated spectrum (D < 0) failed, as shown in Figure S5, which demonstrates the easy-planar magnetic anisotropy of 1.
elements.clean_text:
HF-EPR Studies

In order to further confirm the magnetic anisotropy of compound 1, HF-EPR measurements were performed in the frequency range of 54-315 GHz at 4.2 K. Three main signals can be observed in the HF-EPR spectra of compound 1, which are typical for a spin S = 3/2 Co(II) system with large and positive D values, and they are attributable to the intra-Kramers transitions within the M s = ±1/2 doublets with ΔM s = ±1 (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The field versus frequency dependence of these signals are shown in Figure S5. The simulations of HF-EPR spectra of the compounds utilize the estimated D values (+100 cm-1 for 1) extracted from magnetic measurements. The best parameters obtained are as follows: a g-tensor [g  x  = g  y  = 2.66, g  z  = 3.31], D = +100 cm-1, and |E| = 32.57 for 1. The results further confirmed that the sign of the D value is positive. Meanwhile, the red simulated spectrum (D > 0) is in good agreement with the experimental spectrum while the blue simulated spectrum (D < 0) failed, as shown in Figure S5, which demonstrates the easy-planar magnetic anisotropy of 1.

elements.content:
For the two-dimensional (2D) layered structure of complex 1, we extracted one type of six-coordinate mononuclear unit including one magnetic center CoII ion (see ).

To deeply analyze the magnetic anisotropy, Orca 5.0.3 calculations were performed with CASSCF­(7, 10), followed by N-electron valence second-order perturbation theory (NEVPT2). The spin–orbit coupling (SOC) operator used was the efficient implementation of the multicenter spin–orbit mean-field (SOMF) concept developed by Hess et al. The spin–spin contributions (SSC) to the D values were also included, although they are very small for our complex. In the calculations, the orbitals were determined for an average of 10 S = 3/2 and 40 S = 1/2 roots. All calculations were performed with triple-ζ with one polarization function def2-TZVP basis set for all atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Evaluation of the Magnetic Anisotropy Using Ab Initio Methods

For the two-dimensional (2D) layered structure of complex 1, we extracted one type of six-coordinate mononuclear unit including one magnetic center CoII ion (see ).

To deeply analyze the magnetic anisotropy, Orca 5.0.3 calculations were performed with CASSCF(7, 10), followed by N-electron valence second-order perturbation theory (NEVPT2). The spin-orbit coupling (SOC) operator used was the efficient implementation of the multicenter spin-orbit mean-field (SOMF) concept developed by Hess et al. The spin-spin contributions (SSC) to the D values were also included, although they are very small for our complex. In the calculations, the orbitals were determined for an average of 10 S = 3/2 and 40 S = 1/2 roots. All calculations were performed with triple-ζ with one polarization function def2-TZVP basis set for all atoms.

elements.content: Calculated structure of complex 1; H atoms are omitted for the sake of clarity.
elements.clean_text: 6  Calculated structure of complex 1; H atoms are omitted for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: The zero-field splitting parameters (ZFS) D(E) (cm–1), g (g x , g y , g z ) tensors of complex 1 using NEVPT2 with Orca 5.0.3 are shown in . The calculated positive D value of complex 1 indicates that it is an easy-plane magnetic anisotropy (g x , g y > g z ) (see ). Moreover, the calculated D value obtained from NEVPT2 is slightly larger than the experimental one.
elements.clean_text: The zero-field splitting parameters (ZFS) D(E) (cm-1),  g  (g  x , g  y , g  z ) tensors of complex 1 using NEVPT2 with Orca 5.0.3 are shown in . The calculated positive D value of complex 1 indicates that it is an easy-plane magnetic anisotropy (g  x , g  y  > g  z ) (see ). Moreover, the calculated D value obtained from NEVPT2 is slightly larger than the experimental one.

elements.content: To deeply analyze magnetic anisotropies, we gave the contributions of the excited states to D value for 1 in using NEVPT2 with ORCA 5.0.3. For complex 1, the dominant contributions to the D value from the first and second quartet states are positive, resulting in a positive total D value, which are consistent with the magnetic and EPR results.
elements.clean_text: To deeply analyze magnetic anisotropies, we gave the contributions of the excited states to D value for 1 in  using NEVPT2 with ORCA 5.0.3. For complex 1, the dominant contributions to the D value from the first and second quartet states are positive, resulting in a positive total D value, which are consistent with the magnetic and EPR results.

To probe the structure–property relationship, 2D Co-based SMMs in which Co­(II) displaying octahedron geometry with MOF structure are involved. Some crucial parameters including zero field splitting parameters (D), rhombic anisotropy (E/D), applied field, energy barriers (U eff), and relaxation times (τ0) have been listed in . As seen in , all the compounds show easy-plane anisotropy and negligible rhombic anisotropy with positive D; thus, all the compounds show SMMs behavior under an applied dc field. These results indicate that the six-coordinate octahedron coordination geometry of Co­(II) probably is not an ideal candidate for SMMs. Furthermore, the lattice solvents have a significant effect on the slow relaxation of the compounds. In additional, the Co­(II) ion is highly sensitive to the coordination environments. It is difficult to build the magneto-structural correlation from so few compounds. However, it is clear that coordination geometries, the ligand field and packing patterns are very important influences for above complexes. In addition, intermolecular or intramolecular hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions may also have an unexpected effect on magnetic relaxation dynamics.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetostructural Correlation

To probe the structure-property relationship, 2D Co-based SMMs in which Co(II) displaying octahedron geometry with MOF structure are involved. Some crucial parameters including zero field splitting parameters (D), rhombic anisotropy (E/D), applied field, energy barriers (U eff), and relaxation times (τ0) have been listed in . As seen in , all the compounds show easy-plane anisotropy and negligible rhombic anisotropy with positive D; thus, all the compounds show SMMs behavior under an applied dc field. These results indicate that the six-coordinate octahedron coordination geometry of Co(II) probably is not an ideal candidate for SMMs. Furthermore, the lattice solvents have a significant effect on the slow relaxation of the compounds. In additional, the Co(II) ion is highly sensitive to the coordination environments. It is difficult to build the magneto-structural correlation from so few compounds. However, it is clear that coordination geometries, the ligand field and packing patterns are very important influences for above complexes. In addition, intermolecular or intramolecular hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions may also have an unexpected effect on magnetic relaxation dynamics.

Axial magnetic anisotropy obtained from the fit of the magnetic susceptibility data.

Axial magnetic anisotropy obtained from theory calculations.

Axial magnetic anisotropy obtained from HF-EPR.

In summary, we obtained a compound [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (1) by reaction between CoCl2 and dps, which is similar to previously reported two compounds: [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (2) and [Co­(dps)2Br2] n (3). These results allow us to make a comparison and gain insight into magneto-structural correlations. Magnetization measurements show that 1 is easy-plane anisotropy, which is supported by HF-EPR. This study reveals that the halogen ligands have no influence on the slow magnetic relaxation, while the secondary coordination environment of packing patterns has a significant effect on the slow relaxation, which is rare for MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we obtained a compound [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (1) by reaction between CoCl2 and dps, which is similar to previously reported two compounds: [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (2) and [Co(dps)2Br2] n  (3). These results allow us to make a comparison and gain insight into magneto-structural correlations. Magnetization measurements show that 1 is easy-plane anisotropy, which is supported by HF-EPR. This study reveals that the halogen ligands have no influence on the slow magnetic relaxation, while the secondary coordination environment of packing patterns has a significant effect on the slow relaxation, which is rare for MOF.

elements.content: Dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps, 4 mmol, 0.44 g) and CoCl2·6H2O (2 mmol, 0.476 g) was added to 30 mL of water, heated to 60 °C, and stirred for 3 h to obtain a pink solution, which was filtered and evaporated at room temperature to produce red crystals after a few days. Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C20H16Cl2CoN4S2: C: 47.44, H: 3.19, N: 11.07; found: C: 47.46, H: 3.22, N: 11.05.

Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C20H16Cl2CoN4S2: C: 47.44, H: 3.19, N: 11.07; found: C: 47.46, H: 3.22, N: 11.05.

Experimental Section

[Co(dps)2(C)2] n  (1)

Dipyridin-4-ylsulfane (dps, 4 mmol, 0.44 g) and CoCl2⋅6H2O (2 mmol, 0.476 g) was added to 30 mL of water, heated to 60 °C, and stirred for 3 h to obtain a pink solution, which was filtered and evaporated at room temperature to produce red crystals after a few days. cln_elements.content:
Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials play an important role in coordination chemistry. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a Co­(II)-based MOF [Co­(dps)2Cl2] n (1). Single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure. The magnetic properties studies indicate that compound 1 shows easy-plane anisotropy with positive D value, which is further proved by high-field electron paramagnetic resonance (HF-EPR). AC susceptibility measurements show that compound 1 is field-induced SMM governed by single Co­(II) ion. The magnetic properties studies indicate that coordinate halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. However, the secondary coordination environment of packing pattern has a significant effect on the slow relaxation.

DC Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (DC) susceptibilities of polycrystalline sample were measured under a 1.0 kOe field with a temperature range of 2–300 K. As shown in , the χM T value at 300 K is 3.20 cm3 mol–1 K for 1, which is larger than the theoretical spin-only value of 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K for an isolated high-spin Co­(II) ion (S = 3/2 and g = 2.0). This is due to the contribution of the spin–orbit coupling of Co­(II) ion: upon cooling, the χM T value decreases slowly from room temperature to 150 K and then fast between 150 K and 2 K, reaching a minima value of 1.92 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K.

The field-dependent magnetization of compound 1 was measured in the temperature range from 1.8 to 10 K at the magnetic fields between 0 and 7 T (). The field-dependent magnetizations of compound 1 at 1.8 K and 7 T is below the theoretical saturation value. The plots of M vs HT–1 at different temperature do not overlap clearly (), which confirm the existence of significant magnetic anisotropy attributed to the strong spin–orbit coupling of Co­(II). The data of field-dependent magnetization and temperature was fitted by the PHI program to quantify the anisotropy parameters for 1 using the following spin Hamiltonian: Ĥ = D [ Ŝ z 2 − S ( S + 1 ) 3 ] + E ( Ŝ x 2 − Ŝ y 2 ) + g μ B S H where D and E represent the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting (ZFC) and the last part is the Zeeman. The best fitting results parameters are D = 104.57 cm–1, E = 0.13 cm–1, g = 2.64, and TIP = 1.3 × 10–4 cm3 mol–1 for 1. The positive D values indicate that 1 is easy-plan magnetic anisotropy.

ac susceptibilities were measured at different temperatures from 1.8 K to 7.0 K under a 1500 Oe dc field (). The Cole–Cole plots of χM ′′ vs χM ′ show semicircles for compound 1 from 1.8 K to 6.0 K and can be fitted well using a generalized Debye model by using CC-FIT software (). Therefore, the while frequency-dependent data extracted from Cole–Cole plots in the temperature range of 1.8–5.8 K was fitted by , including three possible relaxation processes: the direct process, the Raman process, and the Orbach process. For , B is the direct coefficient, C and n are coefficients of the Raman process, U eff is the effective energy barrier, T is the temperature, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. The best fitting gave parameters of B = 123.67K –1 S –1, C = 0.707K –n S –1, n = 5.04, τo = 8.82 × 10–7 s and U eff = 28.56 cm–1. τ − 1 = B T + C T n + τ 0 − 1 exp ( − U eff k B T ) From the previous structural analysis, we understand that compounds 1 and 2 have the same formula but different packing patterns and compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing arrangement but different halogen ligands. By comparing the relaxation processes of compounds 1–3, it was found that the relaxation time of compound 2 was the longest, as shown in . In addition, the effective energy barrier of compound 2 was lowest. Since compound 2 does not have the 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework, the distance between Co­(II) in the same plane is the largest, compared to 1 and 3, which probably leads to the lowest energy barrier and the longest relaxation time of 2.

HF-EPR Studies

In order to further confirm the magnetic anisotropy of compound 1, HF-EPR measurements were performed in the frequency range of 54–315 GHz at 4.2 K. Three main signals can be observed in the HF-EPR spectra of compound 1, which are typical for a spin S = 3/2 Co­(II) system with large and positive D values, and they are attributable to the intra-Kramers transitions within the M s = ±1/2 doublets with ΔM s = ±1 (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The field versus frequency dependence of these signals are shown in Figure S5. The simulations of HF-EPR spectra of the compounds utilize the estimated D values (+100 cm–1 for 1) extracted from magnetic measurements. The best parameters obtained are as follows: a g-tensor [g x = g y = 2.66, g z = 3.31], D = +100 cm–1, and |E| = 32.57 for 1. The results further confirmed that the sign of the D value is positive. Meanwhile, the red simulated spectrum (D > 0) is in good agreement with the experimental spectrum while the blue simulated spectrum (D < 0) failed, as shown in Figure S5, which demonstrates the easy-planar magnetic anisotropy of 1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials play an important role in coordination chemistry. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and magnetic properties of a Co(II)-based MOF [Co(dps)2Cl2] n  (1). Single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure. The magnetic properties studies indicate that compound 1 shows easy-plane anisotropy with positive D value, which is further proved by high-field electron paramagnetic resonance (HF-EPR). AC susceptibility measurements show that compound 1 is field-induced SMM governed by single Co(II) ion. The magnetic properties studies indicate that coordinate halogens have almost no effect on the slow magnetic relaxation time and effective energy barrier. However, the secondary coordination environment of packing pattern has a significant effect on the slow relaxation.

DC Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (DC) susceptibilities of polycrystalline sample were measured under a 1.0 kOe field with a temperature range of 2-300 K. As shown in , the χM T value at 300 K is 3.20 cm3 mol-1 K for 1, which is larger than the theoretical spin-only value of 1.875 cm3 mol-1 K for an isolated high-spin Co(II) ion (S = 3/2 and g = 2.0). This is due to the contribution of the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) ion: upon cooling, the χM T value decreases slowly from room temperature to 150 K and then fast between 150 K and 2 K, reaching a minima value of 1.92 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K.

The field-dependent magnetization of compound 1 was measured in the temperature range from 1.8 to 10 K at the magnetic fields between 0 and 7 T (). The field-dependent magnetizations of compound 1 at 1.8 K and 7 T is below the theoretical saturation value. The plots of M vs HT-1 at different temperature do not overlap clearly (), which confirm the existence of significant magnetic anisotropy attributed to the strong spin-orbit coupling of Co(II). The data of field-dependent magnetization and temperature was fitted by the PHI program to quantify the anisotropy parameters for 1 using the following spin Hamiltonian:    Ĥ = D  [    Ŝ   z    2   -   S  ( S + 1 )    3   ]  + E  (    Ŝ   x    2   -    Ŝ   y    2   )  + g   μ   B   S H   where D and E represent the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting (ZFC) and the last part is the Zeeman. The best fitting results parameters are D = 104.57 cm-1, E = 0.13 cm-1, g = 2.64, and TIP = 1.3 × 10-4 cm3 mol-1 for 1. The positive D values indicate that 1 is easy-plan magnetic anisotropy.

ac susceptibilities were measured at different temperatures from 1.8 K to 7.0 K under a 1500 Oe dc field (). The Cole-Cole plots of χM '' vs χM ' show semicircles for compound 1 from 1.8 K to 6.0 K and can be fitted well using a generalized Debye model by using CC-FIT software (). Therefore, the while frequency-dependent data extracted from Cole-Cole plots in the temperature range of 1.8-5.8 K was fitted by , including three possible relaxation processes: the direct process, the Raman process, and the Orbach process. For , B is the direct coefficient, C and n are coefficients of the Raman process, U eff is the effective energy barrier, T is the temperature, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. The best fitting gave parameters of B = 123.67K -1 S -1, C = 0.707K -n  S -1, n = 5.04, τo = 8.82 × 10-7 s and U eff = 28.56 cm-1.      τ   - 1   = B T +   C T   n   +     τ   0     - 1    exp  (   -   U   eff       k   B   T   )    1 From the previous structural analysis, we understand that compounds 1 and 2 have the same formula but different packing patterns and compounds 1 and 3 have the same packing arrangement but different halogen ligands. By comparing the relaxation processes of compounds 1-3, it was found that the relaxation time of compound 2 was the longest, as shown in . In addition, the effective energy barrier of compound 2 was lowest. Since compound 2 does not have the 2-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected framework, the distance between Co(II) in the same plane is the largest, compared to 1 and 3, which probably leads to the lowest energy barrier and the longest relaxation time of 2.

HF-EPR Studies

In order to further confirm the magnetic anisotropy of compound 1, HF-EPR measurements were performed in the frequency range of 54-315 GHz at 4.2 K. Three main signals can be observed in the HF-EPR spectra of compound 1, which are typical for a spin S = 3/2 Co(II) system with large and positive D values, and they are attributable to the intra-Kramers transitions within the M s = ±1/2 doublets with ΔM s = ±1 (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The field versus frequency dependence of these signals are shown in Figure S5. The simulations of HF-EPR spectra of the compounds utilize the estimated D values (+100 cm-1 for 1) extracted from magnetic measurements. The best parameters obtained are as follows: a g-tensor [g  x  = g  y  = 2.66, g  z  = 3.31], D = +100 cm-1, and |E| = 32.57 for 1. The results further confirmed that the sign of the D value is positive. Meanwhile, the red simulated spectrum (D > 0) is in good agreement with the experimental spectrum while the blue simulated spectrum (D < 0) failed, as shown in Figure S5, which demonstrates the easy-planar magnetic anisotropy of 1.

cln_elements.content: The zero-field splitting parameters (ZFS) D(E) (cm–1), g (g x , g y , g z ) tensors of complex 1 using NEVPT2 with Orca 5.0.3 are shown in . The calculated positive D value of complex 1 indicates that it is an easy-plane magnetic anisotropy (g x , g y > g z ) (see ). Moreover, the calculated D value obtained from NEVPT2 is slightly larger than the experimental one.

The calculated positive D value of complex 1 indicates that it is an easy-plane magnetic anisotropy (g  x , g  y  > g  z ) (see ). Moreover, the calculated D value obtained from NEVPT2 is slightly larger than the experimental one.
